Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: 2024 VCE Accounting external assessment report

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The 2024 VCE Accounting examination included eight questions consisting of multiple parts.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Most students were able to complete the examination within the 2 hours allocated. While some students did not attempt every question, this appeared to be due to their knowledge of particular topics rather than running out of time, as they missed questions intermittently throughout the examination. It is important that students cover all areas of the VCE Accounting Study Design throughout the course, as all areas are eligible for assessment in the examination.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Effective use of reading time is a skill that should be practised throughout the year. It is important that students ensure that they read each question thoroughly and highlight the key parts of the question before attempting a response. Many students appeared to have misread questions, resulting in inaccurate responses that did not directly address the requirements of the question.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Terminology is a significant component of the VCE Accounting Study Design. Students should gain, and be able to apply, an understanding of all terminology covered within the course, not just the regularly used terms. When responding to theory questions, students should ensure that they support their responses with terminology, in particular terminology that appears in the Study Design. Correct terms need to be used when describing the change in financial indicators.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Accounting reports were generally handled well by students. Attention to detail when preparing reports is an important skill.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: General Ledger questions were tested throughout the examination, with students being required to post to, balance and close ledger accounts. Most students handled these questions well and were able to score marks for the ledger accounts. Common errors resulting in loss of marks for these questions included the use of incorrect cross-references, reversal of entries and failure to record all entries stipulated within the question.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Modelling questions now appear frequently in VCE Accounting examinations. These questions have developed in complexity since their introduction with the current Study Design. Students are generally achieving high scores in this area of the study.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The 2024 VCE Accounting examination included one discussion question. It was generally handled well by students.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Note: Student responses reproduced in this report have not been corrected for grammar, spelling or factual information.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This report provides sample answers or an indication of what answers may have included. Unless otherwise stated, these are not intended to be exemplary or complete responses.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The statistics in this report may be subject to rounding, resulting in a total of more or less than 100 per cent.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: 2025 VCE Accounting external assessment report

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This report provides sample answers or an indication of what answers may have included. Unless otherwise stated, these are not intended to be exemplary or complete responses

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The statistics in this report may be subject to rounding resulting in a total more or less than 100 per cent.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to record a sales return using the credit note provided. As the cost price of the inventory was provided in the source document, students were required to use the markup of 100% from the information to determine the sales return figure.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: General Journal

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Sales Returns $60 and GST Clearing $6.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accounts Receivable $66.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Inventory $30.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Cost of Sales $30.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the credit note provided by MainRoad Electrics resulted in a sales return. They were also able to apply a 100% mark-up on the inventory that was returned.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included recording the transaction as a sale or a purchase return. Some students recorded the accounts receivable as bank or reversed the inventory and cost of sales.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should ensure that they are able to identify transactions from source documents.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to explain how credit notes can be used as a non-financial indicator of business performance.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Two marks were awarded for an explanation of how credit notes can be used as a non-financial indicator of business performance.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Credit notes can be used to measure customer dissatisfaction. If the number of credit notes issued in a period has decreased over time, this may indicate that more customers are satisfied with the products sold by the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Credit notes also provide important feedback to a business regarding product quality, order handling, dispatch and delivery processes. If the number of credit notes increases, it is an indication of problems with some or all these processes.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses explained how credit notes can be used as a non-financial indicator of business performance by referring to the number of credit notes representing the number of sales returns received by the business. They were able to refer to a higher number of sales returns indicating a negative customer satisfaction (or a lower number representing positive customer satisfaction). As the question did not refer to sales returns, it was possible for higher-scoring responses to take the approach that a higher level of purchase returns indicated a potential issue with the inventory management of the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included referring to financial indicators such as an increase in the value of sales returns. Some students identified the impact on customer satisfaction, although they did not provide an explanation of how the number of credit notes reflected customer satisfaction.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Credit notes verify sales returns so the volume of credit note indicates the number of sales returns. The number of sales returns is a non financial indicator and provides the business with feedback of how satisfied customers where with the inventory in terms of its quality and function. So if there are many credit notes issued by the business it indicates customers are unhappy with the product and aids in decision making such as improving the quality of inventory which can improve performance.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students understand that non-financial indicators can be used when considering business performance.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to show how both the Prepaid Advertising and the Advertising accounts would appear after an adjusting entry was made.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Prepaid Advertising

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Advertising

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Bank $15 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Advertising $5 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Prepaid Advertising $5 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Balance $10 000 (with total $15 000) and Profit and Loss Summary $5 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that they were required to balance and close the accounts, as required on balance day. They identified that GST was not included in prepaid advertising and used accurate cross-references when posting to the ledger accounts.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included wrongly identifying the bank transaction on 10 February as an opening balance. Some students posted the advertising as a credit entry or included GST in the bank transaction in the Prepaid Advertising ledger, or they did not balance and close the accounts on 31 March 2025.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should practise posting transactions directly into General Ledger accounts.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to explain the importance of documents in the accounting process with reference to a qualitative characteristic.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to verifiability as the appropriate qualitative characteristic.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to independent and knowledgeable observers being able to reach a consensus that an event has been faithfully represented.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for expressing that information is supported by source documents which are used as evidence.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses were able to recognise that verifiability was the qualitative characteristic which required source documents to be used in the accounting process. They supported their response by referring to source documents providing evidence which can be used by independent and knowledgeable investors to come to a consensus that an event has been faithfully represented.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included not being able to accurately identify that verifiability requires source documents to be used as evidence or not being able to apply the verifiability definition to support their response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Verifiability ensures that different, knowledgeable and independent observers can come to the consensus that a particular financial information is true. This is upheld by retaining source documents, which can be cross-checked with recorded financial information to verify whether the real-world event has been recorded accurately.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students must develop their understanding of accounting terminology. They should revise qualitative characteristics to provide evidence to support their theory responses.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required student to identify two possible reasons, other than theft, for an inventory loss being incurred by the business. One mark was awarded for each reason.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Possible reasons included (two of):

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: undersupply by suppliers

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: oversupply to customers

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: recording errors in the inventory process where inventory was not recorded by the business

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: wastage that was not recorded by the business

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: damage that was not recorded by the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses identified reasons other than theft which resulted in the business having less inventory on hand than expected.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included not indicating that the reason would result in an inventory loss being incurred, such as referring to recording errors while not referring to how they would result in an inventory loss. Referring to damage or wastage would not result in an inventory loss if the business recorded the impact on the inventory at the time that they occurred. Other common errors were students referring to theft as a reason. This was not acceptable as the question referred to reasons other than theft.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should ensure that they identify the constraints in a question.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to describe an internal control that the business could use to reduce theft, other than security cameras and bag checks already in use by the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for an acceptable internal control.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for a description of the internal control.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Possible internal controls included:

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: employing security guards to patrol the store to deter shoplifters

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: applying security tags to high-value items to reduce the likelihood of theft

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: displaying expensive items in locked display cabinets which would require a staff member to access the inventory.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses described an alternate internal control method to reduce inventory theft. They also identified that the question included a constraint which referred to the business already using security cameras and bag checks.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included not providing a description of the internal control, or referring to security cameras or bag checks despite the explicit constraints cited within the question.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Individual items, such as those that are higher in value, can be security tagged and coded. This allows for staff to be immediately alerted if items are stolen, and gives them the ability to track the inventory as well. This security technology will assist in regaining stolen items, ensuring that the inventory loss does not result from theft, while also discouraging individuals from considering stealing items, so that the risk of theft is fully avoided.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students provide a description when the question requires it, rather than simply identifying an internal control.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to analyse the likely effects on business performance of having an inventory turnover that is much slower than the industry average.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses referred to the slower inventory turnover being due to the business holding inventory for longer than other pet food stores. The business could have a larger range than its competitors which could result in liquidity issues, as the inventory turnover of 90 days is likely to be beyond credit terms which are usually around 30 days. This will result in the business paying for inventory before cash is received from customers. The slower inventory turnover could be an indication of less sales than competitors, which could impact the ability of the business to generate the cash required to pay expenses such as wages and rent.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The potentially wider range of inventory could result in issues with inventory management. The business expects that the inventory loss will be significantly higher than competitors, and a slower inventory turnover could result in an inventory write-down as the pet food approaches its use-by date.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: There could also be additional insurance and storage costs incurred by the business while holding the inventory.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Having a much slower ITO suggests the firm is taking much longer than its competitors to produce inventory into sales. This could cause liquidity problems as the firm might not be producing enough sales to meet its short-term debts such as wages and rent. Furthermore, it puts pressure on the cash cycle of the firm and further worsens liquidity due to the lack of cash to pay its Accounts Payable. Moreover, a slower ITO also suggests more inventory is on hand for the firm than other firms. Given the edible nature of inventory, it is more susceptible to expire and likely get written down or lost hence increasing the inventory loss and write-down expenses of the firm. This decreases profit and the ability to generate profits against the firm's expenses. Hence worsening profitability.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to justify the accountant's suggestion that a change to the First In, First Out (FIFO) inventory cost assignment method would improve efficiency.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to labelling all inventory items if using the Identified Cost assignment method would be a time-consuming and inefficient process for a pet food business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to the FIFO cost assignment method as more efficient and less time consuming as it only requires the details of each product from barcode readers for inventory records to be updated.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for the overall effect on inventory being the same, as pet food would be sold on a regular basis regardless of which method was used.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the costs of labelling each individual item may not be considered important for a business that sells pet food. The inventory is likely to consist of low cost, high turnover goods and the additional cost of labelling would not be offset by any benefits.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included referring to the benefits of selling the oldest inventory first as this would be less likely to go out of date. Students did not recognise that the FIFO cost assignment method is an assumption and does not refer to the actual movement of inventory in the business. Other students referred to the benefits of not incurring the costs of labelling inventory, although they did not apply their response to a pet food store.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: First-in, first-out (FIFO) refers to the assumption that the first inventory in is the first likely sold by the firm, whereas identified cost labels and bags each invoice to determine cost price of sale.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Given the nature of the inventory to be food, it would be very time-consuming to classify inventory by its cost price. Further, it will cost the firm more to spend wages in the process.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: By using first-in, first-out, the firm tends to be more time-efficient and cost-efficient. As the food's cost would not vary much, the cost of sales estimate would be faster and acceptable, hence more efficient.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students understand that the FIFO cost assignment method is an assumption rather than the actual movement of inventory in a business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to prepare a General Journal entry for the credit purchase of inventory.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: General Journal

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Inventory $3 690 and GST Clearing $369.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accounts Payable $4 059.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the cost of the delivery was a product cost as it was a cost incurred by the business to purchase inventory which can be logically allocated to each item. They also recognised that an invoice is evidence of a credit transaction.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included recording the delivery separately. Some students also recorded the Accounts Payable as Bank.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should ensure that they develop their understanding of product and period costing. They should be able to identify that product costs are costs incurred to get inventory into condition and location ready for sale that can be allocated to individual units on a logical basis.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to prepare the General Journal entry to record an inventory write-down. The General Journal entry required a narration.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: General Journal

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Inventory Write-Down $360.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Inventory $360.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark for narration that referred to the inventory write-down of 30 football jumpers and Memo 63.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the reduction in selling price and free coffee cup would result in a reduction in the net realisable value of the football jumpers and an inventory write-down. They used the cost price from the previous question to calculate the inventory write-down.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students who did not score well did not include the coffee cups when calculating the net realisable value or recorded an inventory loss. Some responses did not refer to the football jumpers or include Memo 63 in the narration.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students understand the purpose of a narration. They should focus on the need for a source document and the need to provide additional information to allow the user to understand what occurred in the transaction.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to describe the likely consequences for Top Sportz if the trend in the accounts payable turnover continued.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for correctly referring to the accounts payable turnover becoming slower over the period and being outside the credit terms.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for each consequence described accurately.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Possible consequences included (two of):

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: credit facilities could be withdrawn by the supplier

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: suppliers could cut off the supply of inventory, requiring the business to seek new suppliers

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: a negative impact on the credit rating of the business and why, leading to difficulty in being able to negotiate credit facilities with suppliers in the future.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the business is paying its accounts payable outside of the supplier's credit terms. They also identified and briefly explained more than one consequence.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not providing at least two consequences, or a description of the consequences that they identified.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: If the business continues on a slowing APTO trend and further exceeds credit terms, the supplier might deny further credit facilities to the firm. This would result in the firm not having enough inventory for sales and hence reduce sales and the ability to earn profit.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Further, the Accounts Payable could threaten legal action and as a result the firm could be forced to settle all debts immediately. This is unfavourable as it would mean less cash for other short-term debts such as wages, and possibly force the firm into liquidation. Hence worsening liquidity.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure students develop their understanding of the implications to a business of trends in accounting indicators.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to calculate the GST expected to be paid by the business for November 2025.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for GST on purchase of inventory $5 500.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for GST on advertising $30.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for GST on rent $250.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The total GST expected to be paid in November is $5 780.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the purchase of inventory was not inclusive of GST, and the GST was 10% of the purchase cost. They were able to determine that the advertising expense includes $1 000 of prepaid advertising and therefore the GST was 10% of $300. The GST on rent did not require an adjustment for prepayments and was calculated based on 10% of $2 500.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included calculating GST on inventory using a GST-inclusive approach. GST was recorded as $5 000. GST on advertising was calculated based on the $1 300, rather than the $300 that was paid, and was recorded as $130.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers must ensure that students are able to calculate the GST paid by a business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to prepare the Allowance for Doubtful Debts and Accounts Receivable General Ledger accounts.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Allowance for Doubtful Debts

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Accounts Receivable

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accounts Receivable $2 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Bad Debts $4 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark for Sales/GST Clearing $135 300.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Allowance for Doubtful Debts/GST Clearing $2 200.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Sales Returns/GST Clearing $3 300.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Bank $125 300 and Discount Expense $1 500.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for all correct opening and closing balances.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the Allowance for Doubtful Debts would require an adjustment for a write-off of the bad debt of $2 000. They also recognised that GST was required to be applied to the bad debt write-off in the Accounts Receivable ledger. They used accurate cross-references and to determine the cash received from Accounts Receivable.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included not recording GST in the Sales and Sales Returns transaction. Students reversed the debits and credit entries and recorded balances incorrectly.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should ensure that they practise posting to General Ledger accounts.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to prepare the Operating Activities section of the Budgeted Cash Flow Statement for Dizzies Metalworks for November 2025.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Budgeted Cash Flow Statement for the month ending 30 November 2025

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accounts Receivable $125 300.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Purchases of Inventory ($55 000)

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for GST Paid ($5 780).

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Prepaid Advertising ($300).

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Rent ($2 500) and Wages ($27 000).

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities $34 720.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses used accurate titles in the Cash Flow Statement. They used the information provided to correctly allocate the cash flows relating to operating activities.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included non-cash items in the Cash Flow Statement. Students included GST collected as a cash inflow and discount expense as a cash outflow. Titles were an issue for some students.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should practise the preparation of accounting reports to ensure that they can distinguish between cash and non-cash receipts and payments when preparing a Cash Flow Statement.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to explain why the Budgeted Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities may be higher than the Budgeted Net Profit for the same period.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for budgeted cash flows from operating activities only considering cash received and cash paid in relation to the day-to-day activities of the business. Budgeted Net Profit is calculated by matching revenue earned against expenses incurred in order to determine net profit.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for each example from the information provided, such as:

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Collections from accounts receivable may be greater than the sales revenue for a period if debts from a previous period were all collected in the current period, on top of the receipts from sales in the current period.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The calculation of net profit will often include non-cash expenses like bad debts, depreciation, loss on disposal of assets and discount expense, none of which are outflows in the Cash Flow Statement.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised the difference between budgeted cash flows from operating activities and budgeted net profit. They were able to explain the difference using examples which resulted in cash flows being higher than net profit.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not being able to recognise that operating activities refers to the day-to-day trading activities of the business. Students referred to GST received, although the business only sells on a credit basis and therefore GST is not reported separately in the Cash Flow Statement.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Cash and profit are different resources. The Budgeted Net Cash Flows from Operating Activities is calculated by deducting cash outflows from inflows regarding the expected day-to-day trading activities, whereas the Budgeted Net Profit is obtained on an accrual basis, by deducting budgeted expenses incurred from revenues earned, with revenues being greater than expenses, for the budgeting period. For example, the receipts from Accounts Receivable were greater than credit sales, causing the increase to budgeted operating cash flows to be greater than the increase to budgeted net profit. Additionally, the Budgeted Net Profit is affected by non-cash expenses such as discount expense and bad debts, which decrease the budgeted net profit but not affect budgeted operating cash flows.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students develop their understanding of the difference between net cash and net profit.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to explain one advantage of changing from budgeting on a quarterly basis to a monthly basis.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the business was already preparing its accounts monthly. The move to monthly budgeting would allow for budgets to be more accurate and therefore improve the decision-making process of the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: More regular budgeting would allow for issues to be identified earlier, which would allow for corrective action to be taken earlier.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students referring to the business having more up to date information, although they did make the distinction between actual and budgeted accounts, and some students not recognising that the business was already preparing its accounts monthly.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Budgeting on a more frequent, monthly basis allows the budgets of Dizzies Metalworks to be more timely and accurate in influencing decision-making and planning. This means that corrective action can be taken to resolve adverse trends before it is too late for the business, as budgets are prepared for a shorter length of time, and more frequently.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should have an understanding of the difference between preparing budgeted and actual accounting reports. The business is not required to prepare budgeted reports at the same frequency as their accounting reports.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: This question required students to complete a table to calculate the profit for the business for the 10 pm to 6 am shift, using the current wage of $30 per hour and a hypothetical wage increase of 20%.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Gross Profit $444 and $444.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Staff Wages $240 and $288.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Shift Profit (daily) $204 and $156.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Shift Profit (year) $74 460 and $56 940.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses identified that one staff member was required overnight and to apply that hourly rate for both scenarios.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not applying the gross profit percentage and staff wage rates correctly.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should practise modelling the impact of changes by a business on future accounting reports.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The question required students to discuss whether the 10 pm to 6 am shift should be continued and to make a recommendation to the owner. They needed to refer to both financial and ethical considerations in their response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: If the 20% wage increase was adopted, shift profit would have been below the owner's requirement. If wages are not increased, the owner's requirement is expected to be met. However, the owner should keep in mind that other expenses may increase as a result of operating the night-time shift. Expenses such as lighting, heating, maintenance and possibly security costs may also increase.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The owner's method of determining profit does not take into account these expenses and therefore the profit for the year could be overestimated. The gross margin used in the calculations may also be questionable. Sales of fuel may have a much lower mark-up compared to drinks and food being sold by the business. The night shift may sell more drinks and food during the night as other stores are likely to be closed at that time.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Therefore, the gross profit margin may vary between the day-time shifts and the late night-time shift. This has not been considered in the owner's calculations and perhaps it should be taken into account to get an accurate picture of the situation.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: From an ethical perspective, the night-time shift would be invaluable to the town as it provides a service not available elsewhere. The business also provides a source of income and work experience to young people. However, keeping the business open throughout the night will use more electricity and this may be considered a waste of resources and may be a cause of concern for the environment. There may also be a noise issue for local residents and it may attract some undesirable characters if it continues to operate after midnight. A further issue is the security of staff throughout the night and the potential for an increasing number of 'drive-offs' to occur, which will ultimately affect the profit of the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses applied both the financial information that they modelled, with the non-financial information provided in the question. They provided a recommendation based on a discussion of the financial and ethical considerations that the owner would have taken into account when coming to a decision about the operation of the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Their responses considered the need for the community to have a service station that operated overnight, with the potential risks for employees who would be exposed to antisocial behaviour on the late shifts. They considered the additional costs and environmental impact of opening the service station overnight, with the use of electricity increasing the running costs for the business. Some higher-scoring responses considered the potential for higher margin products, such as food and drink, to be popular with drivers travelling overnight. This could result in a higher gross profit than the owner had budgeted for. When referring to financial information, higher-scoring responses displayed an accurate use of accounting terminology.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students repeating the information provided in the question. While they referred to financial issues, such as the shift profit, and ethical considerations including having a service station available for the community at night, they often provided a limited discussion or no discussion at all.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The shift is not providing the goal target of contributing $60 000 per year to profit, it is financially unfavourable for the firm. Furthermore, the shift is characterised by anti-social behaviour, including theft, which increases the expenses of the firm and therefore reduces net profit, worsening its ability to earn profit. This unfavourable profitability, moreover, could put potentially young employees in danger of anti-social behaviour, and hence the firm should act in a socially responsible and ethical manner to avoid endangering workers.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Moreover, the employee electricity expense is increased, reducing profit, which is financially unfavourable for the firm. However, the owner should also consider the necessity of the shift in the local community as well as the valuable source of income it provides to university students. Customers are likely to be attracted by a more reliable and locally employed shop acting in an ethical manner. This could increase the sales of the firm and hence increase profit, offsetting the increase in wage expense, favourable for the profitability of the firm.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Further, the business is acting ethically by fulfilling the community's needs, aligning to its own. Hence, the owner should continue the shift with the increased wages as well as a suitable staff policy.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should provide the opportunity for students to discuss the ethical and financial consequences of decisions made by business owners.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to explain why a decline in the Return on Assets should be of concern.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to the Return on Assets as an indicator of the efficiency of the asset to generate profit and that the business is generating less profit for each dollar of assets held.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to assets as being less productive and potentially needing to be replaced.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that Return on Assets is a measure of the business' ability to generate profit from its assets. They also recognised that this is a concern because a slower Return on Assets will indicate that the assets may need to be replaced for more productive assets.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not being able to recognise that Return on Assets refers to profit rather than revenue.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: A decline in ROA indicates that the business is becoming less profitable, as they are earning less net profit per dollar of total assets owned, and thus, assets are being used less effectively. This could suggest the business is holding onto assets that are redundant and not helping in revenue-earning significantly, and/or are creating excess expenses, which are concerning issues that should be addressed.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students are able to review trends in accounting indicators and are able to explain the implications of those trends.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to explain how both Sales and the Asset Turnover may increase while the Return on Assets declined.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for identifying a faster Asset Turnover indicating that the business had developed a greater ability to generate sales from its assets.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for identifying that the business was experiencing a decrease in its net profit margin.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for the identification of worsening expense control by the business.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses were able to explain the relationship between Asset Turnover and Return on Assets. As Sales are increasing, the business and Asset Turnover have increased, therefore the business should have experienced an increase in its Return on Assets. But the decrease in the Return on Assets is an indication that there has been a decrease in the Net Profit Margin of the business and therefore the business has worsening expense control.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students being unable to demonstrate an understanding of the Asset Turnover and Return on Assets. Some students displayed an understanding of the Asset Turnover and Return on Assets, but could not explain the relationship between them.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The main difference between ATO and ROA is the consideration of expenses. As sales are increasing while average total assets remain similar or increasing at a slower rate, the ATO will increase. ROA is decreasing even though ATO is increasing, it indicates the business' expense control has worsened significantly and NPM is decreasing. Therefore, the business is retaining less net sales as net profit proportionately, due to expenses, such as depreciation, cost of sale or advertising, which are increasing at a greater rate than sales. Also, ROA is unlikely to improve soon unless expense control is improved.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students are made aware of the relationships between accounting indicators.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to explain how Sales meet the definition of an accounting element.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to revenue as the relevant accounting element.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for an increase in assets (bank or accounts receivable).

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for an increase in owner's equity that is not a contribution by the owner.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses were able to identify revenue as the accounting element. They applied the definition of revenue to Sales and accurately referred to the increase in assets being due to an increase in bank or accounts receivable.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not identifying that revenue was the accounting element, although they provided a rote definition of revenue, and not referring to the increase in assets being bank or accounts receivable. Other students referred to an accounting assumption, including accrual basis, rather than an accounting element.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring student response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Revenue

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Sales indicates an inflow of economic benefit, thus being a revenue. It increases Assets through either Bank or Accounts Receivable and subsequently increases Owner's Equity by increasing Net Profit. It is also not related to any contributions made by the owner.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should revise accounting elements. They should be able to identify the appropriate element and provide evidence to support their response.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to record the necessary adjustments in the General Journal. These adjustments included balance day adjustments and the receipt of a deposit from a customer. Narrations were not required.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: General Journal

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Inventory $1 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Inventory Gain $1 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Wages Expense $1 600.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accrued Wages Expense $1 600.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Insurance Expense $400.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Prepaid Insurance Expense $400.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Depreciation of Equipment $2 500.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accumulated Depreciation of Equipment $2 500.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Electricity Expense $300.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accrued Electricity Expense $300.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Bank $800.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Unearned Sales Revenue $800.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses used correct titles for the General Ledger accounts, including using the asset name (equipment) for the depreciation entry. They were able to calculate the accrued wages expense, insurance expense, depreciation and accrued electricity expense. They were also able to recognise that the deposit received from the customer is recorded as unearned sales revenue.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students recording:

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Accrued Wages Expense of $800, not recognising that there were two days of accrued wages expense

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Insurance Expense as $4 800, not recognising that the business reports monthly

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Depreciation of Equipment of $2 250, but not including the $15 000 of equipment purchased on 1 October 2025

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Unearned Sales Revenue as Unearned Revenue.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers must ensure that students have opportunity to practise recording balance day adjustments. They need to be able to calculate the expense incurred when a prepaid expense is consumed or an accrued expense incurred.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to prepare the Current Liabilities section of the Balance Sheet as at 31 October 2025.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Balance Sheet (extract) as at 31 October 2025

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accounts Payable $42 000 and GST Clearing $2 350.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accrued Electricity Expense $300.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accrued Wages Expense $1 600.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Unearned Sales Revenue $ 800.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that Accrued Electricity Expense, Accrued Wages Expense and Unearned Sales Revenue were required from the adjustments in the previous question.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students reporting Accounts Payable and GST Clearing, without including current liabilities from the balance day adjustments. They included revenues and expenses that are included in a Balance Sheet.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students should practise the preparation of accounting reports. They should be able to prepare extracts of accounting reports, as well as the full reports.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to calculate the depreciation of the traded-in van to 31 December 2024. One mark was awarded for calculating it at $3 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Calculation

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: 6 months of depreciation = $6 000  2

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: = $3 000 is the depreciation of the traded-in van to 31 December 2024.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the traded-in van was held by the business for six months of the year and applied a depreciation rate of 15% to the cost of the asset.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not being able to apply the 15% depreciation rate to the traded-in van that has held for six months of the year. Other students incorrectly included the accumulated depreciation expense over the life of the van, rather than the depreciation expense.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers must show students how to use reading time effectively so that the question that is being asked is specifically addressed and responded to accurately.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to complete the Disposal of Delivery Van account in the General Ledger on 31 December 2024.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Disposal of Delivery Van

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Delivery Van originally costing $40 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Accumulated Depreciation of Delivery Van being $31 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Profit on Disposal of Delivery Van being $1 000 (including $41 000 totals).

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for Delivery Van $10 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses used accurate cross-references when recording the disposal of the delivery van. They were able to identify that the trade-in required the cross-reference to be Delivery Van rather than Bank. They were also able to identify that the business was generating a profit on the disposal of the delivery van.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students not recognising that the $10 000 trade-in was required to be recorded as a credit to the Disposal of Delivery Van. They did not include the $41 000 totals to complete the General Ledger account.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers should ensure that students practise the preparation of General Ledger accounts.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to calculate the depreciation of delivery vans for the year ended 31 December 2025.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to the depreciation on the traded-in delivery van as $3 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to the depreciation on the old delivery van as $7 500.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for referring to the depreciation on the new delivery van as $3 600.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Calculation

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Traded-in delivery van

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: 6 months of depreciation = $6 000  2

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Old Delivery Van

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: New Delivery Van

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Depreciation of delivery vans for the year ended 30 June 2025 = $14 100.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses calculated depreciation on three different vehicles with different costs, each of which were owned for different periods of time.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included students calculating depreciation based on the vehicles being owned for the whole year, rather than for six months as it was purchased on 31 December 2024.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Teachers need to ensure that students practise calculating depreciation when assets are purchased during the financial year.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to complete the table provided to show the effect of the disposal of the old van and the purchase of the new van on the Cash Flow Statement for the year ended 30 June 2025.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Effect on Cash Flow Statement

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for correctly including Investing Outflow at $38 000.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: One mark was awarded for correctly including Operating Outflow at $4 800.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Higher-scoring responses recognised that the business traded in the old delivery van. This resulted in the purchase of the new vehicle, with an investing outflow of $38 000 when allowing for the trade-in of $10 000. They were also able to recognise that the business paid $4 800 on the purchase of the new delivery van.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Common errors included incorrectly recognising the trade-in of the old delivery van as a cash sale and then subsequently including the $10 000 trade-in allowance as an investing inflow. These students recorded the purchase of the new delivery van as $48 000, not allowing for the trade-in.

Subject: Accounting
SectionHeaderContent: Students must be prepared to provide information from accounting reports in a variety of formats.
